newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes weak in thin pre-holiday talk.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes weak in thin pre-holiday talk.

text.p: Late U.S. West Coast light crudes remained solidly lower than yesterday's prices, tracking lower West Texas Intermediate (WTI) oil in an illiquid afternoon market, dealers said.

West Coast spot trade was dead as traders left early for the holidays. No new deals closed today for Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude and its discount remained $1.70 a barrel off WTI a week after the last deal got done.
Outright ANS prices, reacting to flat diffs and soft WTI, were 45 cents lower than Thursday at $24.30/24.50 a barrel.
The dominant seller of ANS stepped out of the market Friday for a holiday function.
Line 63 crude was also lower at $22.85/23.15 a barrel, but no deals were seen on a fixed basis and premiums idled at $0.95 to $1.05.
Kern River prices was flat in late trade after climbing 15 cents to $18.55/18.65 a barrel as companies lifted postings following early week gains in January NYMEX crude.
Discounts remained 10 cents below to even with postings, traders said.
Wilmington crude, produced offshore in Long Beach, Calif., also rose with postings to $20/20.10 a barrel.
